DOCNAME: CASE OF REINHARDT AND SLIMANE-KAÏD v. FRANCE
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Costs and expenses - claim dismissed
TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr PERSON was formerly the chairman of CARDINAL public limited companies ORG ( “ PERSON ” ) and ORG ( “ Servec ” ) , respectively engaged , in particular , in buying equipment for export and in industrial coachbuilding .

On DATE he had also formed with PERSON a private company called ORG ( “ ORG ” ) , whose registered office was at the latter ’s home address and main activity the hire and sale of equipment of all types both in GPE and overseas . On DATE Mr PERSON had replaced PERSON as manager of that company .

CARDINAL . Under CARDINAL commercial agreements the ORG company was to sell industrial vehicles to ORG and deliver “ cab chassis ” on bailment , with ORG being named as bailee , to coachbuilders designated by either ORG or PERSON . It was stipulated that at the end of the bailment and on receipt of payment , ORG would deliver to ORG and PERSON the vehicle test certificates ( feuilles des mines ) of the vehicles concerned and the certificates of sale .
CARDINAL . The description of the facts set out in this and the next paragraph is based on the documents from the domestic proceedings produced to the ORG .

On DATE CARDINAL vehicles belonging to ORG were delivered on bailment to PERSON ’s premises . The periods of bailment were due to end on DATE , DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE ; on those dates PERSON and PERSON were to take up the purchase option on the vehicles and to obtain delivery of the test certificates for each vehicle and the certificates of sale specific to ORG .

At ORG ’s request , a bailiff inspected PERSON ’s premises and drew up an official report on CARDINAL DATE . A court - appointed expert carried out an inspection on DATE and an interim attachment was made on DATE . It was found on the first of those CARDINAL dates that CARDINAL vehicles were missing , on the second that CARDINAL were missing and on the third that CARDINAL were missing . ORG obtained restitution of CARDINAL vehicles ; the others had been registered and sold .

CARDINAL . On DATE an ORG representative reported certain of these matters to ORG ( “ RCID ” ) . Inquiries were made by Detective Inspector PERSON . In a report of DATE he said that the test certificates and certificates of sale of CARDINAL ORG vehicles that had been filed by ORG for registration purposes with the prefecture were forgeries ; he went on to say that offences may have been committed under the companies acts and insolvency legislation in connection with Servec /Provex and to conclude that a judicial investigation was necessary .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG public prosecutor made a written application for an investigation to be opened into offences by an unnamed person of misappropriation and procuring the issue of administrative documents by means of false information , certificates or statements . Mr Candau , the investigating judge , who was assigned to the case DATE , sent instructions on DATE to the head of the Versailles RCID to “ ... continue the investigation with a view to identifying the persons who committed the offences , their co - principals and accomplices ... ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON was taken into police custody and questioned . On DATE the Versailles RCID ’s report was received , PERSON was charged with misappropriation and procuring the issue of administrative documents by means of false information , certificates or statements , and remanded in custody ( until DATE , when the investigating judge ordered his release under judicial supervision ) . On DATE the investigating judge sent instructions to FAC to pursue the investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG public prosecutor made a written application for an additional investigation to be opened into offences of forgery of private , commercial or banking documents by PERSON , who was suspected of having falsified the relevant test certificates and certificates of sale .

CARDINAL . On DATE Iveco – which had joined the proceedings as a civil party claiming damages on DATE made oral submissions and a director of ORG was heard as a witness . On DATE and on DATE Mr PERSON lawyer wrote to the investigating judge enclosing documents for the file . ORG ’s lawyer did likewise on DATE .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON was questioned on CARDINAL and DATE and an ORG executive was heard on DATE . On DATE a confrontation was held between Mr PERSON and an ORG executive and on DATE Mr PERSON was questioned again and charged with forgery of private , commercial or banking documents .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON lawyer wrote to the investigating judge enclosing documents for the file . ORG ’s lawyer did likewise on DATE .
CARDINAL . Since the investigators suspected Mr PERSON of further offences , a second preliminary inquiry was started on DATE into his activities at ORG , PERSON and ORG .

CARDINAL . DATE the Versailles RCID carried out a number of searches and seizures at PERSON home address and on the premises of ORG ; but they also carried out searches and seizures on DATE at PERSON home ( the registered office of ORG ) DATE while she was in custody – and on DATE in a house rented by ORG . On DATE PERSON was questioned by a police investigator .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge had made an order transmitting the file to the public prosecutor for submissions ( ordonnance de soit - communiqué ) . On DATE the ORG public prosecutor made an application for additional charges to be preferred against Mr PERSON for misappropriating company assets , offences equivalent to negligent bankruptcy ( for failure to declare within the statutory time - limit that the company was unable to meet its liabilities ) , fraudulent bankruptcy ( for misappropriation of part of the company ’s assets ) , false accounting and fraud . On DATE Mr PERSON was charged with those offences .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge sent instructions to the head of the Versailles RCID to pursue the investigation into all the offences with which PERSON had been charged .
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON was questioned on CARDINAL and DATE .

CARDINAL . The Versailles RCID sent the investigating judge its report on DATE after carrying out the instructions . On DATE , PERSON , who had been held in custody since DATE , was charged with forgery of private , commercial or banking documents and released under judicial supervision . He was suspected of issuing false invoices to ORG and PERSON and supplying PERSON with the means for committing a like offence .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge sent instructions to the Versailles RCID to pursue the investigation into the offences with which Mr PERSON and PERSON had been charged . The Versailles RCID sent in its report on DATE .

CARDINAL . PERSON was arrested on DATE ; DATE , following an application by the ORG public prosecutor for a further investigation to be opened , she was charged with aiding and abetting the misappropriation of company assets and of handling misappropriated company assets . She was suspected of having given Mr PERSON CARDINAL blank cheques DATE drawn on ORG ’s bank account for a total of MONEY – which she had signed and which PERSON was to make out and endorse DATE and of having benefited from monies fraudulently obtained from that company .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge sent instructions to the Versailles RCID to pursue the investigation into the offences with which Mr PERSON , PERSON and PERSON had been charged .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON lawyer sent a letter to the investigating judge enclosing documents for the file .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Versailles RCID sent in its report pursuant to the investigating judge ’s instructions of CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON and PERSON were questioned on DATE and DATE respectively and PERSON DATE who had been summoned to appear before the investigating judge on DATE , but had not done so – on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge made an order transmitting the file to the public prosecutor for submissions .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON wrote to the investigating judge enclosing documents for the file .

CARDINAL . In a further application of CARDINAL DATE the ORG public prosecutor requested the investigating judge to pursue the investigation into the offences with which Mr PERSON , PERSON and PERSON had been charged and to interview Mr PERSON , PERSON and the managing director of the ORG company .

CARDINAL . On DATE , following a complaint lodged on DATE by ORG ( which joined the proceedings as a civil party claiming damages ) against a person or persons unknown for misappropriation and forgery of commercial documents , the senior investigating judge at ORG made an order transmitting the file to the public prosecutor for submissions .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG public prosecutor applied for an investigation to be opened for misappropriation and forgery of commercial documents by a person or persons unknown . The investigation was to be conducted by Judge PERSON .
CARDINAL . On DATE both investigations were assigned to a different judge , Judge PERSON . He heard VPL ’s representative on CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE Mr PERSON and his lawyer wrote to the investigating judge enclosing documents for the file in connection with the first set of proceedings .
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON was questioned on DATE and DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE VPL ’s lawyer had sent documents to the investigating judge requested by the latter in a letter of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON lawyer wrote to the investigating judge on CARDINAL DATE regarding the hearing of witnesses and inquiries in the first investigation . On DATE CARDINAL ORG ’s lawyer produced documents for the file .
CARDINAL . Instructions were sent on DATE to the GPE RCID for inquiries to continue into the offences with which the CARDINAL suspects had been charged .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge ordered that an expert ’s report be commissioned on the signatures at the foot of the certificates of sale . The expert filed his report on DATE . It was served on ORG on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON wrote to the investigating judge informing him that he had changed lawyers .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Versailles RCID ’s report pursuant to the instructions of CARDINAL DATE was received .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE PERSON wrote to the investigating judge informing him that he had changed lawyers .
CARDINAL . On DATE he was questioned and charged in connection with the second investigation with misappropriation and forging commercial documents .
CARDINAL . On DATE he wrote to the investigating judge informing him that he had changed lawyers .
CARDINAL . On DATE he again appeared before the investigating judge .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE and CARDINAL DATE Mr PERSON or his lawyer wrote to the investigating judge in connection with additional inquiries and the production of documents for the file .
DATE . On DATE a confrontation was held between Mr PERSON and the ORG representative .

CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE , CARDINAL and DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE and DATE and DATE , PERSON or his lawyer wrote to the investigating judge in connection with additional inquiries and the production of documents for the file .

CARDINAL . On DATE , in connection with the first investigation concerning PERSON , the investigating judge instructed the ORG police superintendent to “ inspect the ORG vehicle registration file for DATE and DATE ” and “ to seize and place official seals on the originals of the test certificates ” .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ’s lawyer wrote to the investigating judge and produced documents for the file .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge heard an ORG representative . Documents were produced for the file .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Versailles RCID ’s report on the instructions of CARDINAL DATE was sent to the investigating judge .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON lawyer wrote to the investigating judge enclosing documents for the file relating to the first investigation ; a lawyer acting for CARDINAL of the civil parties did likewise on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge heard Mr PERSON , who both at that hearing and under cover of a letter of DATE produced documents for the file .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON requested an expert audit of ORG ’s accounts . The request was renewed by his lawyer on DATE , but turned down by the investigating judge on DATE . Mr PERSON appealed against that decision on DATE but , following submissions on DATE by ORG at ORG , the President of ORG of that court refused , in an order of CARDINAL DATE , to refer the request to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ’s lawyer had written to the investigating judge and produced documents for the file . PERSON lawyer did likewise on DATE in connection with the second investigation .

CARDINAL . By an order of the president of the ORG tribunal de grande instance on DATE , Judge PERSON was replaced by Judge PERSON . On DATE Judge PERSON ordered the transmission of the file to the public prosecutor for submissions with a view to joinder of the CARDINAL sets of proceedings ; the public prosecutor sought an order to that effect DATE . On DATE the investigating judge made CARDINAL orders : the first for joinder of the CARDINAL sets of proceedings and the second for transmission of the file to the public prosecutor . On DATE the public prosecutor made final submissions requesting the committal of Mr PERSON , PERSON and PERSON to the criminal court . On DATE Judge PERSON made a committal order .
CARDINAL . ORG held a hearing on DATE .
On DATE Mr PERSON lawyer wrote to the president of that court enclosing documents for the file , as did ORG ’s lawyer on CARDINAL DATE . PERSON lawyer forwarded further documents on DATE .
On DATE the criminal court decided to extend its deliberations until CARDINAL NovemberCARDINAL .
On CARDINAL and DATE respectively ORG and PERSON lawyers wrote to the president of that court enclosing documents for the file .

CARDINAL . Judgment was delivered on DATE . PERSON was found guilty of misappropriation , forging private , commercial or banking documents , fraud , false accounting and misappropriation of company assets and sentenced to DATE imprisonment , CARDINAL of which were suspended ; he was barred from carrying on any business activity for DATE . PERSON was given a sentence of DATE months’ imprisonment for forging private , commercial or banking documents and aiding and abetting the forgery of commercial documents and PERSON a DATE suspended sentence for aiding and abetting the misappropriation of company assets . The court declared the civil party claims of ORG and VPL inadmissible .
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON appealed to ORG on DATE , as did the public prosecutor 's office , PERSON , Mr PERSON and ORG on DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE respectively .

CARDINAL . According to the Government , on DATE and CARDINAL DATE a summons was issued requiring a representative of VPL to appear , but the company could not be located . PERSON , ORG , the liquidator of PERSON ( Mr NORP ) and PERSON were summonsed on DATE , DATE and DATE DATE and CARDINAL DATE respectively .
CARDINAL . At the hearing on DATE CARDINAL PERSON , Mr PERSON and ORG lodged their submissions . The hearing was adjourned to CARDINAL DATE to enable summonses to be served on PERSON and VPL .
Summonses were issued against PERSON on DATE and , according to the Government , against VPL on DATE , but neither could be located .

CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was adjourned for the last time to CARDINAL DATE to enable summonses to be served on VPL and Mr PERSON , the liquidator acting in the joint liquidation of GPE , PERSON and ORG .
Summonses were issued against VPL on DATE and CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG acquitted PERSON PERSON on the count of misappropriation of company assets , upheld the guilty verdict on the other counts and confirmed the sentence . It increased PERSON sentence to a term of CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , suspended , and reduced PERSON sentence to DATE . It upheld the judgment of the trial court in all other respects .
CARDINAL . PERSON and PERSON lodged appeals on points of law with ORG that DATE . Mr PERSON and ORG did likewise on CARDINAL and DATE . PERSON also appealed .
The case file was sent to ORG on DATE and assigned to a reporting judge on DATE .
ORG lodged written pleadings on DATE , followed by Mr PERSON and PERSON on DATE . On DATE ORG lodged CARDINAL , and PERSON two , written pleadings .
The reporting judge filed his report on DATE and the advocate - general was appointed on DATE .
PERSON filed written pleadings on DATE and DATE . VPL and Mr PERSON filed pleadings on DATE .
DATE . According to the Government , it is unlikely that the advocate - general prepared his submissions in writing as he intended to present them orally at the hearing .

The Government further maintained that at the hearing of ORG on DATE , which took place without the applicant ’s representatives being present , the reporting judge addressed the court and oral submissions were made by the advocate - general .

CARDINAL . In a decision delivered on DATE , ORG , relying on the reporting judge ’s report , the parties’ pleadings and the submissions of the advocate - general , dismissed the appeals of those who had been convicted .

CARDINAL . ORG is composed of the president , the divisional presidents , the judges , the auxiliary judges , ORG , ORG , the advocates - general , the senior registrar and the divisional registrars ( Article PERSON of LAW ) .

It is divided into CARDINAL civil divisions and CARDINAL criminal division , each comprising a divisional president , judges , auxiliary judges , CARDINAL or more advocates - general and a divisional registrar ( Articles PERSON , PERSON and PERSON ) . The divisions are subdivided into sections , in which formation most appeals are heard .

CARDINAL . Judgments of an ORG and judgments delivered by an assize court , a criminal court or a police court sitting as a court of last instance may , if they are not in accordance with the law , be set aside on an appeal on points of law by either the public prosecutor 's office attached to the court which delivered the judgment or the party adversely affected ( LAW ) .

In criminal cases , ORG at ORG may appeal to that court only for the purposes of clarifying the law ( pourvoi dans l’intérêt de la loi ) . In such cases , he appeals either on formal instructions from the Minister of Justice ( Article CARDINAL ) or of his own motion against a judgment delivered by an assize court , a criminal court or a police court sitting as a court of last instance where none of the parties has entered an appeal within the set time - limit ( Article CARDINAL ) ; in the event of an appeal by ORG of his own motion , if the appeal is allowed the judgment is reversed but the parties may not rely on ORG ruling to contest execution of the judgment that has been set aside ( ibid . ) .

CARDINAL . As soon as the case file is received by the registry of ORG , the president of that division appoints a reporting judge ( LAW ) from among the judges and the auxiliary judges ; the latter have a vote at deliberations on appeals in which they are appointed as reporting judge ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . The reporting judge draws up a written report in which he carries out a thorough review of the case , sets out the legal arguments deduced from the grounds of appeal , indicates what research he has carried out into legal opinion and case - law on the basis of the grounds of appeal and states his recommendations . He also prepares a draft judgment , which is distributed to each of his colleagues as a basis for discussion at deliberations .

The case file lodged by the reporting judge is sent by the registry , with the report and draft judgment , to the advocate - general assigned to the case by ORG . Counsel for the parties are informed of the recommendation in the report ( appeal to be declared inadmissible , or to be dismissed , allowed in part or in full ) by an entry in the list of cases that is distributed DATE before the hearing to lawyers practising in the PERSON d’Etat and ORG .

In principle , any additional pleading filed at this stage will be declared inadmissible ( LAW ) . However , ORG has a discretion and it appears that examples of its declaring inadmissible pleadings filed late are rare ( see PERSON , ORG at ORG , “ NORP en cassation ” , Juris - classeur procédure pénale , DATE , fascicule CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Principal State Counsel 's Office at ORG does not act as a prosecuting authority before that court . Except in appeals made for the purposes of clarifying the law , it acts only as a party joined to the criminal proceedings . Its role is not to argue the prosecution ’s case but to ensure that the law is correctly applied ( see “ NORP en cassation ” , cited above , and PERSON , ORG , Juris - classeur procédure pénale , DATE ) .

PERSON , Advocate - General at ORG , thus explains that whereas the role of the prosecution consists , in principle , of law enforcement and upholding the law , the role of ORG Office at ORG is confined to the latter task . In that capacity it is required to ensure that the law is correctly applied when it is clear and correctly construed when ambiguous ( PERSON , “ ORG et Cour suprême ” , PERSON juridique , Doctrine ( DATE ) , PERSON . PERSON no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . NORP The duties of ORG in ORG are “ personally conferred on ORG ” ( Article R. CARDINAL - CARDINAL of LAW ) . Save for directions to lodge an appeal for the purposes of clarification of the law , ORG does not receive any instructions regarding the performance of his duties ( see for example the speech made on DATE by PERSON , ORG at ORG , at the formal ceremony marking the beginning of the judicial year , GPE documentation française , GPE DATE , and the “ ORG et Cour suprême ” article cited above ) .

ORG “ assigns ORG and the advocates - general to the divisions in which he considers they may most usefully serve ” ( Article R. CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) . ORG and the advocates - general “ speak on behalf of ORG in the divisions to which they have been appointed ” ( Article PERSON ) . In important cases their submissions are communicated to ORG , who , if he is not in agreement and the advocate - general refuses to amend them , may delegate another advocate - general or make submissions himself at the hearing ( Article R. CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) . It appears , however , that that provision has never been applied and that in practice the advocates - general are , therefore , free to decide on the tenor of their submissions ( see the “ NORP en cassation ” article cited above ) .

In his speech of DATE ( referred to above ) PERSON explained : “ [ the ] value of the work [ of the advocate - general ] , which is performed after the reporting judge has completed his task , is as a ‘ second GPE . Either the advocate - general agrees with the report , in which eventuality the decision to be taken will be clearer , or he disagrees , and will have triggered the necessary debate . In all cases his role is somewhat ‘ maieutic’ . ”
DATE . The advocate - general ’s submissions do not have to be in writing .

CARDINAL . NORP The list of hearings is fixed DATE . A single advocate - general deals with all cases on the list for DATE he is on duty . He informs the relevant lawyers practising in the ORG d’Etat and ORG , who , if they wish to make oral submissions , must advise the president before the hearing .

CARDINAL . DATE before the hearing a preparatory “ meeting ” is held between the president and the senior judge of the division and the advocate - general on duty for DATE ; they systematically review the cases on the list and exchange views ( see the “ Pourvoi en cassation ” and “ ORG et Cour suprême ” articles cited above and the speech given on DATE by Mr PERSON , ORG at ORG , entitled “ PERSON général à la PERSON et la Convention européenne de sauvegarde des ORG , GPE palais , CARDINAL DATE ) . It appears to be customary after the meeting for the advocate - general to inform the lawyers acting in the case of the tenor of his submissions ( see the speech entitled “ PERSON général à la PERSON et la Convention européenne de sauvegarde des ORG l’Homme ” cited above ) .

In parallel , the reporting judge ’s report is studied in detail by the offices of the president and the senior judge , which give a reasoned opinion in writing . Their opinion , together with the submissions of the advocate - general , are communicated to the reporting judge DATE before the hearing ( see the “ NORP en cassation ” article cited above ) .
CARDINAL . Hearings of ORG are held in public and the procedure is the same as that in the other courts ( LAW ) .

The procedure before ORG is nevertheless in written form ; the parties’ lawyers are not required to appear at hearings . In ORG there is an oral hearing only in the ( rare ) cases where the parties’ lawyers have expressly requested CARDINAL .

At the hearing the reporting judge is the first to address the court . He reads out his report but does not disclose his recommendations . If there are to be oral submissions , counsel for the appellant addresses the court first followed by counsel for the respondent ; they may not submit any new legal argument . The advocate - general is the last to address the court ; he makes submissions that are confined to legal issues and may concern the consideration of a ground of appeal raised by the court of its own motion ( Article CARDINAL of LAW ; and see the “ NORP en cassation ” article cited above ) . It would appear that where oral submissions are made it is customary to allow the parties to reply to the advocate - general ’s submissions , either orally or by a note addressed to the court in deliberations ( see the speeches of Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON referred to above ) .

CARDINAL . After the public hearing , the members of the court deliberate in private . The reporting judge gives his opinion ; the other judges and the president then express their views . Following a vote on whether the recommendations of the report should be adopted , the draft judgment , which each judge will have received DATE beforehand , is then considered ( LAW ; and see also the “ NORP en cassation ” article cited above ) .

The advocate - general generally attends the deliberations . In that connection , Mr PERSON explained in his speech of DATE ( cited above ) : “ ... practice on this point is settled . If it is an important case that has ( exceptionally ) been pleaded by counsel , the advocate - general leaves the courtroom at the same time as the parties and the public in order clearly to demonstrate that the judges deliberate alone . In ordinary cases , the advocate - general usually remains in his seat but does not take part in the debate . His presence results from purely practical considerations relating to the number of cases , which is often substantial , to be heard at each sitting . It has no special signification ” ( see also Mr PERSON ’s speech referred to above ) .
CARDINAL . The judgment in its adopted form is then finalised and delivered at a public hearing , in most cases immediately after the deliberations .
